information:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No, Post Malone will not win an award, as ACM voters tend to favor established country artists over cross-genre newcomers, and he faces very strong competition in all his nominated categories.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Academy voters favor more traditional country artists like Morgan Wallen, Lainey Wilson, and Chris Stapleton, or the heavily-nominated newcomer Ella Langley. Despite the commercial success of his work, voters perceive his foray into country as inauthentic or opportunistic, and he is shut out in all five of his nominated categories, continuing his streak of receiving numerous major award nominations without a win.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The massive commercial success of the collaboration "I Had Some Help" with Morgan Wallen proves too significant for voters to ignore. Following a precedent of awarding successful cross-genre collaborations, the ACM awards him and Wallen in one of the categories for their song, such as Single of the Year or Music Event of the Year, acknowledging the song's impact and its role in bringing new audiences to the genre.
forecast.rationale: My forecast is based on Post Malone's status as a newcomer to the country genre facing established industry voting patterns. The key factors influencing my forecast are the strong competition, the mixed history of crossover artists at country award shows, and Post Malone's personal track record at major awards. He has five nominations, which gives him multiple opportunities to win. His strongest chances lie with his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help," as its immense commercial success and Wallen's star power make it a formidable contender. There is precedent for crossover collaborations winning major country awards (e.g., Lil Nas X, Justin Timberlake). However, the status quo suggests a 'No' outcome. Country music award voters are often traditionalists, and the top awards frequently go to established genre mainstays. The competition is fierce, with artists like Ella Langley, Morgan Wallen, Lainey Wilson, and Chris Stapleton all having more or an equal number of nominations and deeper roots in the genre. Furthermore, Post Malone's history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations (18) without any wins suggests a pattern of being recognized by nominating committees but failing to secure enough votes to win, which could repeat here. My probability is not higher because the headwinds of voter traditionalism and strong competition from established country acts make winning an uphill battle. It is not lower because five nominations, three of which are for a mega-hit with one of country's biggest stars, give him several very plausible paths to a victory, especially in a collaborative category. I would increase my forecast if prominent country music insiders began predicting a win for him, or if a comparable awards show rewarded the same work. I would decrease it if sentiment from reporting on industry voters indicated a strong consolidation behind a more traditional candidate in his key categories.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Post Malone win an award at the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards?

Question background:
The awards are scheduled to be held on May 8, 2025. Malone has 4 nominations.


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Post Malone wins an award at the [60th Academy of Country Music Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60th_Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards).




Your research assistant's report says:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

Today is 2025-04-22.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
